facts.text: Dispute about possession of a plot of land between appellant's party and Darshan deceased's party.
Appellant and twelve other persons tried with him assaulted Darshan deceased and his companions when they were returning from fields.
Darshan and his companions struck appellant's party in self-defence.
In the incident, Darshan and Nand Lal received injuries; Daya Ram, Hamela and Kartar Singh (appellant) received injuries on appellant's side.
Darshan died on account of injuries received.

Daya Ram stated that when he, Kartar Singh, Hamela and others were going near their field, Darshan, Nand Lal and others sitting on a well challenged them; Nand Lal remarked he would not let Daya Ram escape; fight ensued; injuries inflicted on each other; Daya Ram did not know who speared Darshan.
Kartar Singh stated a member of Nand Lal's party caused spear blow to his abdomen; he ran away; did not cause any injury.
Hamela stated Darshan and others assaulted his party when going to plough disputed land; caused injuries in self-defence.
Both parties instead of resorting to law wanted to force issue by force of arms; collected persons from Seel and other villages armed with spears, gandasis, sticks; had pre-concerted pitched fight.
Sessions Judge acquitted ten accused giving benefit of doubt; convicted Daya Ram, Hamela, Kartar Singh as they admitted presence and received injuries; participation proved.
Sessions Judge felt Daya Ram, Hamela, Kartar were accompanied by at least 9 or 10 persons but difficult to say who.
High Court held large number on appellant's side exceeding five; appellant's party formed unlawful assembly with common object to cause injuries resulting in death.
No evidence of more than five on appellant's side per appellants; other party aggressor.
Witnesses from Seel; accused from other villages; only PW 22,23 named all 13; others named up to 7; all said 13 in appellant's party.
Darshan had two incised wounds and one punctured wound; Nand Lal had two incised wounds, one punctured wound, two abrasions.
Kartar Singh not connected with land dispute but went armed with others.

legal_issues.text: When ten out of thirteen charged acquitted, can remaining three constitute unlawful assembly?
In a free fight, is each participant liable only for own individual act?

petitioner_arguments.text: No evidence more than five in fight on appellant's side; Sessions Judge acquitted other ten specifically named by PWs; cannot convict under 302/307 r/w 149.
Appellant not proved to cause injury to Darshan or Nand Lal; liable only for individual act in free fight.

respondent_arguments.text: Large number exceeding five on appellant's side; unlawful assembly with common object to cause injuries resulting in death.
No question of right of private defence; clear case of free fight; immaterial who started.

court_reasoning.text: Courts below could find actual number more than five; acquittal of named ten does not preclude others; witnesses inconsistent in naming; possible more than five.
court_reasoning.key_observation: State of evidence allows conclusion of more than five in appellant's party.

court_reasoning.text: Finding of unlawful assembly correct; constructive liability under s.149.
In free fight where party prepared and armed, no right of private defence; common object to commit offence; liable under s.149 for acts in furtherance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rejects individual liability; cites Gore Lal.

court_reasoning.text: Even if not more than five, common intention under s.34 justified; armed and determined to fight.

holdings.text: Appellant's party constituted unlawful assembly; conviction under ss.302/307 r/w 149 IPC correct.
In pre-concerted free fight by armed parties, participants liable constructively under s.149 for injuries in furtherance of common object.
Alternatively, conviction sustainable under ss.302/307 r/w 34 IPC.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Mistaken identity unlikely where accused known; here witnesses from different villages, inconsistent naming allows possibility of more than five.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gore Lal v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: In prepared free fight, who attacks/defends immaterial; confirmed conviction under 307 r/w 149.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Conviction under 302/307 r/w 149 for murder/attempt to murder by unlawful assembly member; alternatively r/w 34 for common intention.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; conviction and sentence under ss.302 and 307 r/w s.149 IPC upheld as appellant's party formed unlawful assembly in pre-concerted free fight; alternatively sustainable under s.34.

key_quotes.text: "both the parties, in order to assert their rights, had a free fight which was pre-concerted with the set purpose of forcing the issue mentioned above."
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court

key_quotes.text: "When it is held that the appellants party was prepared for a fight and to have had no right of private defence, it must follow that their intention to fight and cause injuries to the other party amounted to their having a common object to commit an offence."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes common object for s.149 liability.

key_quotes.text: "the conviction under s.302 and s.307 read with s.149 can be converted into one under s.302 and s.307 read with s.34."
key_quotes.speaker: court
